Situation1: They encounter a customer trying to return an item without a receipt and need to apply the store’s return policy.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story:
I stand behind the register, scanning items with practiced ease, when a woman approaches, clutching a blender and looking anxious. She explains she lost her receipt but needs to return it—the blender broke after just a week. Store policy is clear: no returns without proof of purchase. My manager expects me to enforce this, no exceptions. I see her frustration, and I want to help, but I know I could get in trouble for bending the rules. 

At the same time, my mind drifts to my other responsibilities. I’ve been carefully organizing my tax documents, determined to file early and do my part as a responsible citizen. I also saw the flyer for the free vaccine clinic this weekend. I want to volunteer, to help my neighbors stay healthy, but I’m scheduled for a long shift at the store. 

I feel pulled in different directions—by the rules I’m supposed to uphold at work, and by my desire to support my community and do what’s right. The woman’s hopeful eyes meet mine, and I hesitate, caught between the expectations of my job and my sense of duty as a citizen.
